One thing that has not been mentioned in this video is that when you sweat, you not only lose water, but also electrolytes, which are a bit more complicated to replenish (and lack of which can also increase the feeling of tiredness).
I remember that as a child, when I played football in the sun on a warm day, I then craved salty snacks like crazy. Preferably potato crisps, which, next to salt, also have a lot of potassium. Not that I recommend potato crisps to any health-conscious people, but they were the best sodium-potassium combo available in every store for a person that can't afford anything but a quick and convenient snack.

The heat wave in Washington was my first ever experience with heat exhaustion. We don't have built in ac, and so on the hottest day just for shits and giggles I went outside to experience it.

I wasn't out for a couple seconds before I was slammed with a wave of nausea. Shits no joke. We had to drive around in my car with the dog because the power went out.

Tips from a former lifeguard: These reasons presented here are why we 1) always have cold beverages on hand, and 2) take frequent dips into the much cooler water during our shifts, as well as 3) staying a good deal of time under the shade of parasols (beach umbrellas). When in doubt, just ask a lifeguard. Legally, we have to be certified in basic rescue and injury emergency medical response.

P..S. My only water rescue was of a near-drowned dragonfly, legs up, apparently not responsive, found in a pool filter. As a new lacto-ovo Vegetarian (now Vegan), I was concerned, so I literally just gently stroked its thorax and abdomen to restore respiration, expecting nothing. After a couple minutes, it started breathing on its own, righted itself, then sat on my shoulder warmkng up in sunlight for about three minutes, before flying away into the Michigan late morning sun. That was Summer of 1988, and it's still one of the proudest days of my life.

I grew up with cats. We had two cats - one grey and white, one black with a thick undercoat....

I swear, our grey-and-white cat was a furry solar panel. He would go out in the yard on a hot sunny day, find the hottest, sunniest corner and bake himself. Our black cat stayed in the shade... preferably on the cold, damp cement patio after someone had hosed grass clippings off it. He didn't like the heat. Maybe a good thing.... when he did stay long in the sun, his black coat heated up so much, you could burn yourself if you touched him.

Life hack: Way to treat a sunburn:
Apply cold/cool clean water to clean towel on burn, leave on while the towel drys, re wet and reapply until your sunburn heals.
It will cool down your skin, it will reapply moisture, both will speed up healing and reduce pain.
